Award.AwardTitle: CSEDI Collaborative Research: Application of Siderophile Elements to Early Earth Processes and Mantle Mixing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Siderophile elements are those chemical elements with a strong preference for metal compared to silicates. For the Earth, the abundances of these elements were strongly affected by segregation of the metallic core, and also likely affected by processes that occurred exclusively in the silicate portion of the early Earth (mantle and crust). For this project, we will conduct collaborative, synergistic research combining observations of siderophile element concentrations and isotopic compositions, with geodynamic modeling to study the origin and evolution of chemical heterogeneities in Earth's early mantle. The outcome of this work will be an improved understanding of the global processes that led to the establishment of siderophile element abundances in the mantle, as well as provide new insights to the differentiation and mixing histories of the mantle. One specific task will be to examine the petrologic and chronologic extents of 182W isotopic anomalies in terrestrial rocks. As the decay product of the short-lived 182Hf (tÂ½ = 9 million years), variations in 182W likely reflect processes that occurred within the mantle during the first 30 million years of Earth history. Both ancient rocks, such as komatiites for which we have already identified isotopic anomalies, and modern rocks, such as mid-ocean ridge basalts, oceanic peridotites, and ocean island basalts will be examined. Complementary to this work, we will model large-scale processes, such as magma ocean crystallization, with the potential to generate mantle domains characterized by the elemental abundances and fractionations necessary to produce the observed isotopic variances.

This project will involve serious contributions from undergraduate participants at the University of Maryland (UMd). As such, some of the research proposed here will help to indoctrinate budding scientists in the methods used in isotopic geochemistry and geodynamic modeling, as well as the presentation of results. The project will also involve postdocs at both institutions. The collaborative nature of the proposal, as well as the close proximity of the UMd and Carnegie Institution for Science, will allow frequent, direct interactions involving both geochemical data acquisition and geodynamic modeling of the results for the PI?s and postdocs working on this project.

ProgramElement.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTHS DEEP INT

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interior of the Earth has a range of compositions and chemistries, which we learn about through material brought to the surface by volcanoes, and through the action of seismic waves as they travel through the Earth. Near the metal core there appears to be a layer of dense material that only occasionally sends wisps of its unusual composition to the surface in magmas. In the shallow mantle, just under the continents, the rocks are much more oxygenated than those at depth, but the reasons for these differences are not obvious.

 Researchers have developed several possible processes that would create these different compositions. Most of these proposed processes require special conditions of accretion of our planet in the first place, such as early accretion of highly reduced, metal-rich material, and later accretion of oxygenated rocky material that could not include metals.

 In a search for a simple, consistent process that could explain multiple observations of compositional heterogeneities, we have pursued the model of a magma ocean. As the Earth neared its current size, within the first 100 million years of our 4.568 billion-year-old solar system, the Earth sustained a series of large powerful impacts of accreting material. The last of these giant impacts produced our Moon, and melted the outside of the Earth perhaps as deeply as the core-mantle boundary. We have spent the last 15 years modeling the process of solidification of the Earth and tracking the compositional changes this solidification would create.

 We have discovered, through work under this grant, that the same magma ocean solidification processes can result in both the trace element and isotopic differences we measure between the deepest mantle near the core and the surface, and also the change over that depth range in the oxidation state of the mantle. Previous work has shown that these same magma ocean processes can explain the water content of the Earth, without later additions of water-rich material.

 Having one simple model of an inescapable process in Earth formation explain three separate chemical observations lends great credence to the model and process being proposed. Since one or more magma ocean stages appear to be inevitable during the accretion of a rocky planet, we are putting together a strong argument for a simple process requiring no special pleading to explain the compositional heterogeneity and volatile content of our planet. Further, the ubiquity of magma oceans in planetary formation indicates that these predictions and observations can be used for understanding rocky exoplanets, and for the search for habitable planets outside the Earth.
